HMS ''Perseverance'' |unit= |battles=Capture of the [[French frigate Résolue (1778)|Résolue]], 1791 |awards= |relations=James Cook}} '''Isaac Smith''' (1752–1831) was a [[Rear Admiral]] in the [[Royal Navy]] and cousin of the wife of Captain [[James Cook]], with whom he sailed on two voyages of exploration in the South Pacific. Smith was the first European to set foot in eastern [[Australia]] and the first to prepare survey maps of various Pacific islands and coastlines including [[Tierra del Fuego]] in South America. ==Early life== Smith was born in [[London]] in 1752, the eldest of seven children of Charles and Hannah Smith and cousin to James Cook's wife Elizabeth.Robson 2009, pp. 175-176 He enlisted for naval service in 1767 at the age of thirteen, using his family connections to secure an immediate ranking of [[Able seaman (rank)#Royal Navy|able seaman]] and a position aboard [[HMS Grenville (1754)|HMS ''Grenville'']] under Cook's command, for a survey voyage off the west coast of Newfoundland. On 27 May 1768, and still ranked able seaman, he transferred to his second vessel, Cook's [[HMS Endeavour|''Endeavour'']], at DeptfordBeaglehole 1968, p. 590 ahead of its expedition to the Pacific to observe the 1769 [[Transit of Venus]]Rigby and van der Merwe 2002, p. 24 and then to search the south Pacific for signs of the postulated ''Terra Australis Incognita'' (or "unknown southern land").{{cite web |title=Secret Instructions to Lieutenant Cook 30 July 1768 (UK) |publisher=National Library of Australia |year=2005 |url=http://www.foundingdocs.gov.au/item.asp?dID=34 |accessdate=26 August 2008}} ===Pacific exploration=== [[File:Midhsipman Isaac Smith.jpg|thumb|left|300px|[[Midshipman]] Isaac Smith depicted in c.1770 as a crew member aboard [[HMS Endeavour]]. Oil painting by [[Richard Cosway]]]] {{main|First voyage of James Cook}} Smith sailed with Cook to [[Tahiti]], then to [[New Zealand]] and the east coast of Australia.Blainey 2008, p. 18 On 28 April 1770 he became the first European to set foot on eastern Australian soil, Cook telling him "Jump out, Isaac" as the ship's boat touched the shore at Botany Bay.{{cite news| last =Maclean |first =Donald |title =Coasting With Cook: A Cruise in Historic Waters | work =The Argus | page =9 | publisher =Argus Office, Melbourne Victoria | date =5 August 1933 | url =http://ndpbeta.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/4753582?searchTerm=isaac+smith+cook+endeavour | accessdate =20 July 2009 }} A month later on 23 May 1770, Smith was promoted to [[midshipman]] following [[James Magra]]'s suspension on suspicion of having assaulted Cook's clerk. Cook's lieutenant [[Zachary Hicks]] died from [[tuberculosis]] in May 1771, and was replaced by the [[master's mate]] [[Charles Clerke]]. In turn, Smith was promoted to fill Clerke's former role and served with distinction for the remainder of the voyage.Hough 1994, p. 210 Cook singled him out in a letter to the [[Secretary of the Admiralty]] in 1772, noting that Smith "had been of great use to me in assisting to make Surveys, Drawings &c in which he is very expert."Cook, James, Admiralty 1/1609, cited in Hough 1994, p. 216 Smith sailed again with Cook in 1772, as master's mate aboard the [[HMS Resolution (1771)|HMS ''Resolution'']].Hough 1994, p. 231 He assisted first mate Joseph Gilbert in drawing Cook's maps and survey charts during the voyage, including one of the first recorded maps of Tierra del Fuego in 1773.Hough 1994, p. 301 Smith's wider artistic talents were also demonstrated by the production of a small [[watercolour]] of icebergs, painted while ''Resolution'' sailed close to [[Antarctica]] in 1773.Rigby and van der Merwe 2002, p. 103 On ''Resolution''{{'}}s return Cook again singled Smith out for praise, advising Admiralty that he was "a Young man bred to the Sea under my care and who has been a very great assistant to me in [making charts], both in this and my former voyage."Letter from Captain James Cook, R.N to the Admiralty Secretary, 24 May 1775, cited in Robson 2009, p. 175 ===Independent command=== On ''Resolution''′s return to England in 1775, Smith was promoted to lieutenant and given command of the elderly 16-gun [[sloop]] {{HMS|Weazel|1745|6}}, holding this post for two years.Hough 1994, p. 319 In December 1787, he was promoted to [[post-captain]] in command of the 36-gun frigate HMS ''Perseverance.''Urban 1831, p. 178 The future Admiral [[John Surman Carden]] was a member of Smith's crew from 1787 to 1793, before his transfer to the [[HMS Marlborough (1767)|HMS ''Marlborough'']]. As captain of ''Perseverance'', Smith was assigned to the [[East Indies Station]] under the overall command of Admiral [[William Cornwallis]] and took part in the capture at sea of the French frigate [[French frigate Résolue (1778)|Résolue]] in 1791 at the [[Battle of Tellicherry]], shortly before the outbreak of the first [[French Revolutionary War]]. ==Later life== Despite this achievement and continued commendation from his superiors, Smith's active service days were drawing to a close. In 1794 he contracted [[hepatitis]], and his ill health gradually prevented him from performing his duties. In either 1804Besant 2009, p. 180 or 1807 he applied for and received a promotion to the superannuated post of [[Rear Admiral]] and returned to England to retire. In initial retirement Smith shared a house in Clapham with his cousin, Cook's widow Elizabeth, until in the 1820s he inherited [[Merton Priory|Merton Abbey]] in Merton, Surrey, from his brother in law. He then divided his time between these two homes, until his death on 2 July 1831 at the age of 78.{{cite web| title =Maritime Memorials | publisher =National Maritime Museum (UK) | year =2009 | url =http://www.nmm.ac.uk/memorials/Memorial.cfm?Banner=5&MemorialPage=7&MemorialID=M5555&Full=Transcript | accessdate =20 July 2009 }} His will left a sum of £700 to the church of St Mary the Virgin in Merton, the interest from which was to support the poor of the parish.{{cite book |title =A Topographical Dictionary of England: Mersea, East - Methwold | first =Samuel | last =Lewis (ed.) | year =1848 | publisher =Institute of Historical Research | pages =295–298 | url = | isbn =}} cited in {{cite web| title =British History Online | publisher =University of London & History of Parliament Trust | year =2009 | url =http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=51145 | accessdate =19 July 2009 }} A memorial to Smith, originally financed by Elizabeth Cook, stands in the church grounds.{{cite web| title =St. Mary the Virgin | publisher =Merton Council (UK)|date=December 2006 | url =http://www.merton.gov.uk/leisure/history-heritage/heritage-sites/stmarythevirgin.htm | accessdate =20 July 2009 }} == References == {{reflist|30em}} == Bibliography == *{{cite book |title =Captain Cook | first =Walter | last =Besant | year =2009 | publisher =BiblioLife | url =https://books.google.com/books?id=QgXCYhzmr8EC&pg=PA180&lpg=PA180&dq=%22isaac+smith%22+cook+admiral&source=bl&ots=BaK1iTuquB&sig=EKuEj3fE4rp8gyer7KEvWmiyQ5k&hl=en&ei=l75jStCkNI_0sQPmrq3xAQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1 | isbn =978-1-103-06135-8 }} *{{cite book |title =The Journals of Captain James Cook on His Voyages of Discovery, vol.
